title: 109_s654
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Convention Against Torture Implementation Act of 2005" and prohibits certain transfers of persons. The "Convention Against Torture Implementation Act of 2005" prohibits the expulsion, return, or extradition of individuals to countries on a list submitted by the Secretary of State or where there are substantial grounds for believing they would be subjected to torture. The Secretary of State can waive this prohibition with congressional certification. The "Convention Against Torture Implementation Act of 2005" prohibits expulsion, return, or extradition to countries on the Secretary of State's list where torture is likely. Waivers can be granted with congressional approval if torture is no longer occurring and safeguards are in place to prevent it. The "Convention Against Torture Implementation Act of 2005" allows waivers for transferring individuals to countries where torture is likely, with a report required to be submitted to congressional committees detailing the transfer. Reports should be unclassified but may include a classified annex for national security purposes. The "Convention Against Torture Implementation Act of 2005" allows extradition or removal of individuals under certain conditions, with the option to challenge based on risk of torture. Assurances from foreign governments are not enough to guarantee safety from torture. The "Convention Against Torture Implementation Act of 2005" allows extradition or removal of individuals under certain conditions, with the option to challenge based on risk of torture, believing that a person is not in danger of being subjected to torture. The "Convention Against Torture Implementation Act of 2005" requires the Secretary of State to submit an annual report listing countries where torture is known to be used. Additionally, regulations are outlined in the Act. SEC. 4. REGULATIONS.

Interim regulations must be prescribed within 60 days of the Act's effective date to implement obligations under the Convention Against Torture. Final regulations must be prescribed within 180 days after a period of public comment.

SEC. 5. SAVINGS CLAUSE. SEC. 5. SAVINGS CLAUSE.

This Act does not affect the obligations of the United States or individual rights under the Convention Against Torture or any other applicable law. Section 2242 of the Foreign Affairs Reform and Restructuring Act of 1998 is repealed, and existing regulations will remain in effect until new interim regulations are issued. In this Act, "appropriate government agencies" refer to the intelligence community and various federal law enforcement, national security, intelligence, or homeland security agencies that have custody or control of persons outside the United States. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. The term "Convention Against Torture" refers to the United Nations Convention Against Torture. The United Nations Convention Against Torture, signed by the United States in 1988 and ratified in 1994, defines terms like expelled, extradited, and returned persons. The United Nations Convention Against Torture, signed by the United States in 1988 and ratified in 1994, defines terms like expelled, extradited, and returned persons. A returned person is someone transferred from one country to another where they are a national or have previously resided. The terms in this Act align with those in the Convention Against Torture, with any reservations, understandings, declarations, and provisos from the Senate resolution. SEC. 8. EFFECTIVE DATE.

This Act will take effect 30 days after enactment.

SEC. 9. CLASSIFICATION IN UNITED STATES CODE.

This Act will be classified in the United States Code under a new chapter of title 50.
